      </tr>

      <tr>
        <td id="L10" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="10"></td>
        <td id="LC10" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Given the recent rise in popularity of craft beer, a new generation of beer pioneers has been created that no longer is satisfied with the standard beer styles offered by big commerical breweries, such as ABInbev. Among the most popular of the craft beer styles is the Imperial Pale Ale, often referred to a the &quot;IPA&quot;. It has become a major source of revenue for many craft breweries as the trend has sweeped the globe. In order to compete, AbInbev has been discussing the potential of releasing a &quot;Budweiser IPA&quot;, which will be a market response to promote Budweiser to a wider audience. The following exploratory analysis aims to provide a thorough understanding of what defines an IPA, along with the best suggestion for a regional trial.</td>
      </tr>

      <tr>

        <td id="LC66" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">&lt;p style=&quot;color:#99bbff&quot;&gt;<span class="pl-mi">*In order to investigate the number of breweries in our data set, we group everything by state and then perform a tally function in order to count total breweries.       <tr>
        <td id="L68" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="68"></td>
        <td id="LC68" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">According the dataset provided, it appears that the states with the highest craft brewery count (in order) are Colorado, California,  Michigan, Oregan, and Texas. From here, we can make an initial inference that these markets are most appreciative towards craft beer and would provide a great test market for the new IPA release.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L69" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="69"></td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L120" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="120"></td>
        <td id="LC120" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">&lt;p style=&quot;color:#99bbff&quot;&gt;<span class="pl-mi">*How can we address the &quot;NA&quot; values? In order to get a better idea of missing data, we filtered the dataframe to only null values using &quot;is.na&quot; and then took the count of each column using &quot;colSums&quot;. You can see in the print statement below that the most influencial null value is ibu. Almost half of the ibu values are missing! In order to &quot;massage&quot; this into workable data, we made an assumption that the median values for each style should be fairly close to the actual values. This is due to the fact that each beer style has ranges on ibu, therefore, we know a good range of potential values which the actual could lie in. *&lt;/p&gt;</span></td>
      </tr>

        <td id="LC122" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mi">In order to use the dataset for future statistical modeling and machine learning projects, it&#39;s important to treat any missing values in the dataset.       <tr>
        <td id="L135" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="135"></td>
        <td id="LC135" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">You can see how by providing a median value, we were able to reduce the missing IBU values to 52 (see ibu_corr) and the missing ABV values to 0 (see abv_corr).</td>

        <td id="LC137" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> based on evidence, will use median abv and ibu per beer style to fill na</span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L138" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="138"></td>
        <td id="LC138" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">main</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">main</span> %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>% group_by(<span class="pl-smi">beer_style</span>) %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>% mutate(<span class="pl-v">ibu_corr</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> ifelse(is.na(<span class="pl-smi">ibu</span>), median(<span class="pl-smi">ibu</span>, <span class="pl-v">na.rm</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">TRUE</span>), <span class="pl-smi">ibu</span>), <span class="pl-v">abv_corr</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> ifelse(is.na(<span class="pl-smi">abv</span>), median(<span class="pl-smi">abv</span>, <span class="pl-v">na.rm</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">TRUE</span>), <span class="pl-smi">abv</span>))</span></td>

      <tr>

        <td id="LC149" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">#</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Part 4: Median ABV and IBU for entire dataset.</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L150" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="150"></td>
        <td id="LC150" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">&lt;p style=&quot;color:#99bbff&quot;&gt;<span class="pl-mi">*After checking for null values, we then compute the median ABV and IBU for the dataset to give a representation of the central values to expect among all beers. We accomplish this using a grouping statement and then dplyr&#39;s summarise statement in order to perform a median aggregation on each column. *&lt;/p&gt;</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L151" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="151"></td>
        <td id="LC151" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mi">\newline</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L152" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="152"></td>
        <td id="LC152" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mi">What ABV and IBU levels do craft beer consumers gravitate towards? Where does traditional Budweiser fall on this scale? Based on the evidence in the dataset provided, the median ABV of the craft beer for each state provided is between 4 - 6.7%. This is a fairly tight spread, suggesting that an ABV level between the median ranges would likely be suitable to consumers in all states. </span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L153" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="153"></td>
        <td id="LC153" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mi">\newline</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L154" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="154"></td>
        <td id="LC154" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mi">However, when looking at the median IBU values, there is much more spread between states. What this would suggest is that different states have different views on how bitter their beer should be (IBU level). Currenlty, traditional Budweiser resides right in the middle of the ABV range at 5% ABV, but much lower than the median IBU for all states in the dataset (12 IBU)! Therefore, the evidence suggests that craft beer consumers might prefer Budweiser if it were more bitter (greater IBU). </span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L155" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="155"></td>
        <td id="LC155" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mi">```{r message=FALSE}</span></td>
